ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Professor would simply explain the lesson on his paper on zoom and I'd take notes by hand.
Posted notes online, online explorations, and online concept checks.
live virtual lecture, class size ~15-20
none
Online homework quizzes
Mostly zoom live lecture combined with optional online videos.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Problem-solving skills and a better understanding of different Calculus 2 topics (e.g. sequences and series, parametric equations, integration strategies, etc.)
Math 115 skills such as more complex integration strategies, tests for convergence, as well as information on parametric and polars.

I learned more about several important topics of calculus such as techniques of integration, series, parametric and polar equations, etc. I gained a deeper understanding of how to work through more complicated problems and incorporating several concepts to solve a problem.
I learned how to integrate functions.
Volumes of solid of revolution, lots and lots of integrals, applications of integrals and series. Like Calculus BC in regards to content

This course covered mechanical calculus techniques, including methods of integration, area and volume computations, and finding polar and parametric coordinates and tangents. The course also helped me understand visualization of calculus concepts, including graphical approximation curves and revolutions of solids.
Learned different ways to take integrals as wells as evaluate infinite series. Also learned the basics of parametric and polar equations and their calculus.
I expanded on the calculus knowledge I learnt in high school, and developed the skills to solve more complex problems.
Solve integrals
I learned how to find the convergence of series, how to find volumes of revolutions, and how to do integration/differentiation involving polar curves.
I learned Calc 2 principles such as different methods of integration, evaluating sequences and series, finding volume under a curved rotated, etc.
I dont believe I developed any considerable knowledge, skills, or insight.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Plenty of resources available to help you do well. Problem sets and practice exams closely matched actual exams. Develop problem-solving skills.

Weaknesses: The weekly exploration assignments were not as helpful as they were intended to be. The professor was not very receptive to the questions that were left on the explorations. Also, the notes at the end of each exploration generally stopped being useful after they stopped using videos.
It was very easy to be unfocused in class as it was not that engaging.
I sometimes found the explorations and concept checks to be easy, but then the problem sets would be really hard.

Strengths: Lots of help available in terms of office hours, peer tutors and email
Weakness: The course depends on the quality of your instructor, so it might vary a bit

Some of the course's strengths were the sequence of units, the exploration assignments, and availability of peer tutoring and office hours. The only weakness of the course was the occasional failure to integrate textbook concepts into classroom lessons. This could be easily fixed by doing a review of the problem set concepts before class.

Strengths: The schedule was well thought out and time to each subject was allocated well.
Weaknesses: the lectures were not recorded so it was sometimes difficult to review past material depending on your professor's notes. Talking to other people in the class it was obvious some profs were better than others.

I would have learnt better if the classes/lectures had been recorded. I still would have liked to attend them live, but having to option to watch the class back again to catch things I missed would have been highly beneficial for me as I find it harder to concentrate when learning online.
Small lecture size was nice. Professor kind of mean.
The assessments accurately reflected the material we covered however it was hard to stay engaged in an online lecture format.

The course is very lecture heavy and participation heavy which weakens it due to the social aspect of zoom wherein people participate less. I feel that having recorded lectures would also be beneficial due to different time zones and being able to look back and slow down explanations of harder math concepts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professors for Math 115 did not really put anything into place to make learning easier during the pandemic. It would have been especially helpful if the review sessions for midterms would have been recorded, but this was not the case.
I think the format was pretty good given the circumstances. With it being online it was pretty easy to miss some steps if the professor worked quickly.
Breakout rooms are typically more awkward than helpful. I liked having virtual office hours because it was easier to fit into my schedule.

Succeeded: more flexibility in office hours and online review sessions
What could be improved: Better information sharing in the umbrella math website

The practices that succeeded were the clear filmography of class notes projected by the professor, constant open questions to the class when examples were being computed, and pausing to see if the entire class was following what was being written. Something that could be improved was placing groups into breakout rooms to do practice problems. I found that oftentimes, groups would not do the problems during the time allocated.
I think the lectures should have been recorded.

As mentioned about, I would have preferred if the classes had been recorded as I find it harder to concentrate when learning online and so would have liked to have been able to refer back to the class content. Also, as an international student who began studying remotely, this class was late at night for me and it would have been better if it had been recorded. I liked the small-ish class size as it gave opportunities for everyone to ask questions.
The small lecture size was good. That was all.
The online quizzes we did helped introduce new topics but the online lectures were hard to stay engaged with.
Online learning proved to be very tough, especially since the process of learning was very much just lecture-based, and it was very difficult and tough to do group work.

Breakout rooms on Zoom to workout problems were very unhelpful and a waste time because of lack of peer-peer interaction. Essentially, people were too scared they were wrong and didnt have friendship ties that gave them the security to attempt problems. Alongside this, the absence of recorded lecture made it even more difficult to properly absorb information. Online office hours were very useful and helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course if you enjoyed calculus in high school and want to continue learning it in college, especially if you're looking to fulfill a QR credit. This is also a requirement for econ, math, and probably a couple of other majors so if you're considering those areas of study, definitely take it!
If they want to major in math or a math related field and enjoy math I would, otherwise probably not.

Yes, for students who are interested in taking more math classes in the future or very interested in STEM. This course introduces several topics that are important later on and it will help you hone your mathematical reasoning and problem-solving skills.
I would recommend this course to another student if they enjoy math.
Yes if you need to fill your QR. It is not too difficult

I would recommend this course to another student! It was very thorough, and the concepts taught could be applied in many other contexts. The progression of course material was in a perfect order, and there are many opportunities to seek help from peer tutors and professors.
It was ok if you are decent at math and need it as a prerequisite to your major.
Yes, if they need to take math or are interested in calculus. I wouldn't recommend it as a 'fun' course, just because math is math.
Its a fine math class to take if you need it but if you dont like math dont take it.
Yes if you need to take Calc 2
Yes
Unless my peers needed the course to fulfill their math requirements, I wouldnt recommend course.
